Dispute_Type: Citizenship eligibility based on residence requirement
Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge's decision adequately explained how the residence requirement was met
Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions in evidence regarding applicant's residency were not addressed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with residence requirement
Credibility_Factor: Applicant resided in France since 2005 while applying for Canadian citizenship
Legal_Rule: Residence requirement for naturalization must be substantively and procedurally satisfied
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for adequacy of reasons; reasonableness for residence determination
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide adequate reasoning by decision maker
Grounds_for_Claim: Inadequate explanation from citizenship judge on residence compliance
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision found unreasonable due to lack of reasoned analysis
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Decision lacked procedural fairness due to insufficient reasoning
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's prolonged residence in France since 2005
Legal_Framework: Canadian citizenship law, administrative law principles
Applicant_Challenge: Demonstrating physical presence in Canada for citizenship
Court_Result: Decision annulled and remanded to another citizenship judge
Evidence_Type: Residency records, application forms, testimonial or documentary evidence
Legal_Provision: Section 5(1) of the Citizenship Act â€“ residence requirement
Legal_Provision_Cited: Citizenship Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-29, s. 5
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet physical residence requirement for citizenship
Governing_Rule: Residence requirement for naturalization under Canadian law
